newsitem.title: HONG KONG: TABLE TENNIS-SWEDEN'S SVENSSON PREVENTS CHINA SWEEP.
newsitem.headline: TABLE TENNIS-SWEDEN'S SVENSSON PREVENTS CHINA SWEEP.

text.p: Olympic champion Deng Yaping
powered towards the richest prize in women's table tennis with a
straight games victory over former China team mate Jing Jun Hong
in the World Cup quarter-finals on Sunday.
The world number one beat Jing, who now represents
Singapore, 21-14 21-18 21-12 to stay on course for the US$22,000
winner's cheque.
The Atlanta gold medallist was briefly in trouble at 8-13 in
the first game but won 11 points in succession with great
attacking play to sink Jing.
Deng will play Sweden's Marie Svensson in the semifinals.
Svensson, world number 47, prevented an all-Chinese last
four when she beat world number 23 Ni Xia Lian 21-19 21-13 19-21
The 1994 European champion hit top form to defeat Ni, a
former Chinese squad member now representing Luxembourg.
"I enjoy playing against the best players in the world and
there is really no pressure on me as I'm not expected to win,"
said Svensson, who returned from a six-month injury lay-off at
the Atlanta Games in July.
The other semifinal will be between China's world number
five Wang Chen and Yang Ying, ranked one place lower.
Wang, winner of two events on the women's circuit this
season, swept past Hong Kong's world number eight Chai Po-wa
Yang beat another home player, Chan Tan-lui, 21-10 21-17
